title: Clinton ‘Not Concerned’ About New Flap Over Classified Emails
content:
DES MOINES , Iowa – Hillary Clinton sought to minimize new disclosures that top secret government information passed through the private email server she used when she was secretary of state , dismissing the controversy as an “ inter-agency dispute ” that pales next to the larger issues on the minds of voters .
In an interview with NBC News on Saturday morning , two days before the Iowa caucuses , Mrs. Clinton said , “ It ’ s the same story that ’ s been going on for months now . And I just don ’ t think most people are as concerned about that as they are about what we ’ re going to do to get the economy going . ”
The State Department on Friday said it was withholding in their entirety 22 documents from an archive of Mrs. Clinton ’ s emails being publicly released , saying they contained material so sensitive that it could not even be shared in redacted form .
The department also said it was opening an investigation into whether the emails were classified at the time they were sent or received . Officials have previously said the redactions in the roughly 43,000 pages of her emails so far released were made for information that was classified only after the fact .
Mrs. Clinton ’ s exclusive use of a private email account and a server kept at her home Chappaqua , N.Y. , has weighed on her campaign since she entered the race last April . Her refusal to use the standard-issue government account has fueled perceptions that she is secretive in her dealings and wanted to shield her communications from public records requests .
Mrs. Clinton has denied such charges , saying she merely wanted the “ convenience ” of using a single device rather than carrying one for work and another for personal correspondence . She has also said she never sent or received any emails marked classified at the time . What is happening , she said , is different federal agencies are arguing among themselves about whether certain information in her email records was classified .
The FBI is looking into her email arrangement and Republican critics have said she should face legal consequences for what they say was an unconventional email practice that put government secrets at risk .
The Republican National Committee , in a statement Friday , said that “ any doubt about whether Clinton discussed some of the government ’ s most highly classified information on her secret email server can now be cast aside . ”
In the NBC News interview , Mrs. Clinton said , “ I ’ m really not concerned . ”
“ This doesn ’ t change anything about the fundamental facts , ” she said . “ I never sent or received any email marked ‘ classified. ’ I take classified information very seriously . I want to get things out and I want to people to understand based on what happened and when it was happening in real time there were no classification markings , and that ’ s what you have to be guided by . ”
State Department Says 22 Clinton Emails Are Too Classified to Release
Who Will Win the Iowa Caucus ? It Depends on Who Shows Up

content_original:
DES MOINES, Iowa – Hillary Clinton sought to minimize new disclosures that top secret government information passed through the private email server she used when she was secretary of state, dismissing the controversy as an “inter-agency dispute” that pales next to the larger issues on the minds of voters.

In an interview with NBC News on Saturday morning, two days before the Iowa caucuses, Mrs. Clinton said, “It’s the same story that’s been going on for months now. And I just don’t think most people are as concerned about that as they are about what we’re going to do to get the economy going.”

The State Department on Friday said it was withholding in their entirety 22 documents from an archive of Mrs. Clinton’s emails being publicly released, saying they contained material so sensitive that it could not even be shared in redacted form.

The department also said it was opening an investigation into whether the emails were classified at the time they were sent or received. Officials have previously said the redactions in the roughly 43,000 pages of her emails so far released were made for information that was classified only after the fact.

Mrs. Clinton’s exclusive use of a private email account and a server kept at her home Chappaqua, N.Y., has weighed on her campaign since she entered the race last April. Her refusal to use the standard-issue government account has fueled perceptions that she is secretive in her dealings and wanted to shield her communications from public records requests.

Mrs. Clinton has denied such charges, saying she merely wanted the “convenience” of using a single device rather than carrying one for work and another for personal correspondence. She has also said she never sent or received any emails marked classified at the time. What is happening, she said, is different federal agencies are arguing among themselves about whether certain information in her email records was classified.

The FBI is looking into her email arrangement and Republican critics have said she should face legal consequences for what they say was an unconventional email practice that put government secrets at risk.

The Republican National Committee, in a statement Friday, said that “any doubt about whether Clinton discussed some of the government’s most highly classified information on her secret email server can now be cast aside.”

In the NBC News interview, Mrs. Clinton said, “I’m really not concerned.”

“This doesn’t change anything about the fundamental facts,” she said. “I never sent or received any email marked ‘classified.’ I take classified information very seriously. I want to get things out and I want to people to understand based on what happened and when it was happening in real time there were no classification markings, and that’s what you have to be guided by.”
